docs.lead_paragraph: For many adults, the mention of the President's Physical Fitness Test conjures up images of sprinting between two chalkboard erasers and doing sit ups to exhaustion. For those with fond memories of this grade school gym class standard there is now a grown up version of it called Strend, a challenging six-event contest that is attracting more and more competitors. Strend is an acronym derived from the first three letters of ''strength'' and ''endurance.'' Each Strend competition includes five upper-body strength events -- bench presses, pull-ups, military presses, chin-ups and bar dips followed by a three-mile run. The first Strend contest in 1992 was little more than a group workout. There are now four to six events a year in several United States cities and throughout Germany. A world championship features 50 competitors and offers prize money for the top three men and women.
docs.abstract: Strend, challenging six-event physical fitness contest, is attracting more and more competitors; Strend is an acronym derived from first three letters of 'strength' and 'endurance'; each Strend competition includes five upper-body strength events--bench presses, pull-ups, military presses, chin-ups and bar dips followed by three-mile run; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Dr. Atkins's diet is the only diet that helps me survive. I am allergic to almost everything: pollen, dust, mold, chocolate, dairy products, some vegetables, wheat and even some vitamins and minerals. Now that I eat Dr. Atkins's way, I am losing weight for the first time in my life, having never been able to follow a diet past a 10-pound weight loss. In a few months, I have lost 30 pounds and I continue to lose. And, it does not aggravate my allergies. I had my cholesterol levels and lots more checked and all of them are within the normal levels. I'm not a doctor, but I don't believe that it takes a rocket scientist to figure out that this diet has many bonuses. MICHELLE HEADY Fort Pierce, Fla.
docs.abstract: Michelle Heady letter on Jane E Brody's May 25 article on Atkins diet

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In her column on the Atkins diet, Jane Brody cites among her sources three or four friends who did not fare so well on low-carbohydrate diets.
docs.abstract: Donna Valentino letter on Jane E Brody's column on the Atkins diet
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    In her column on the Atkins diet, Jane Brody cites among her sources three or four friends who did not fare so well on low-carbohydrate diets.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I am concerned that the article ''A New Look at Dieting: Fat Can Be a Friend'' has added more confusion to an already bewildered public and may discourage many people from making changes in diet that might have given them substantial benefits. I recommend a whole foods diet, based on fruits, vegetables, whole grains and beans in their natural forms, which are high in complex carbohydrates, low in simple carbohydrates and very low in fat and cholesterol. The studies cited were based on simple, not complex, carbohydrates. There is a big difference.
docs.abstract: Dr Dean Ornish letter comments on May 25 article on dieting; stresses dietary importance of complex carbohydrates rather than simple carbohydrates; assails high-protein, high-fat diet advocated by Dr Robert C Atkins
